problem: Dave rode 30 miles at 10 miles per hour and 10 miles at 30 miles per hour. What was his average speed, in miles per hour, for the entire ride?
solution:
Dave rode a total of $40$ miles.  The $30$ mile segment took $\frac{30}{10}=3$ hours, while the $10$ mile segment took $\frac{10}{30}=\frac{1}{3}$ hours, so the full ride took $3+\frac{1}{3}=\frac{10}{3}$ hours.

So the average speed was  $\frac{40}{\frac{10}{3}}=\boxed{12}$ miles per hour.
model_solution:
Step 1: Calculate the time taken for each segment of the ride. 
Time = Distance / Speed
Step 2: Calculate the total time taken for the entire ride by adding the time taken for each segment. 

Total Time = (30 miles / 10 mph) + (10 miles / 30 mph)
Step 3: Calculate the average speed for the entire ride.
Average Speed = Total Distance / Total Time
= (30 miles + 10 miles) / Total Time
Total Time = (30 miles / 10 mph) + (10 miles / 30 mph)
= 3 hours + (1/3) hours
= 3 1/3 hours
= 10/3 hours

Average Speed = Total Distance / Total Time
= (30 miles + 10 miles) / (10/3 hours)
= 40 miles / (10/3 hours)
= (120/3) / (10/3)
= 120/10
= 12
Average Speed = Total Distance / Total Time
= (30 miles + 10 miles) / (10/3 hours)
= 40 miles / (10/3 hours)
= (120/3) / (10/3)
Average Speed = (120/3) / (10/3)
Average Speed = (120/3) / (10/3) 
= 12
Average Speed = Total Distance / Total Time
= 40 miles / (10/3 hours)
= (120/3) / (10/3) 
= 12
Final Answer
